author: potuz
content: Loved the Meta section, I believe the tooling for rollback in consensus and the such is very important, we have been advocating for it for a long time, problem is that everyone is on a time crunch and there isn't really a return over investment in trying to coordinate this. So each client is slowly going their own route in trying to slowly implement mitigation tactics. Prysm has opened a series of issues and we have merged a couple of PRs allowing blocks to be blacklisted, LH and others can start from an unfinalized checkpoint, etc... But these are being produced without a central coordination of the features. Even though it goes against the eth/acc movement of the latest few weeks (years?) we do need to take a few months to breathe and think about these issues with some perspective and actual time for implementation

author: jochembrouwer
content:
This one was a wake up call for me:

> The failure of the Pectra upgrade on Holesky illustrated a mistake in our thinking; testnets are not the same thing as pre-production environments. While core devs think of networks like Holesky as testnets, fit for breaking, applications and service providers think of them as where they test their deployments before going to production. This incongruity needs to be corrected, so both audiences may be served during our development lifecycle.

author: timbeiko
content: One thing I'll note though is that many of the designs that would allow Ethereum to recover from issues can also be used to censor in certain circumstances, so we should be extremely mindful about what we choose to spec, implement and deploy.

author: tersec
content: The other broad consideration would be plausibility at scale, i.e. being realistic about how many individual actors would have to act how quickly. So e.g., finalization delays, they wouldn't have helped Holesky at all because it didn't finalize, only justify. But even justification delays wouldn't have helped in a network where it wouldn't be plausible to get most of the stake to react in a fairly short timeframe. For Holesky, there was a kind of plausible attempt to stop things within literal single-digit minutes. Never happening on mainnet with any "social consensus"-based mechanism, so how long would such a delay have to be?

author: tersec
content: And to the extent it relies on quick acting, does it implicitly mean home stakers are now viewed as against the interest of the Ethereum ecosystem because it's not their job to administer fleets, so they can't react quickly?

author: timbeiko
content:
**ACDE Recap**

1. Pectra:
  - Mainnet tentatively scheduled for 2025-04-30 14:14:47 (slot 11599872). To be confirmed on ACDC next week. Will also follow up with infra/app teams by then to flag issues. 
  - We'll be using the template in Fredrik's fork process to coordinate the fork (https://github.com/ethereum/pm/pull/1409)
  - We'll wait until Fusaka to try out https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7910

2. Fusaka: 
  - After a lot of back and forth: **EOF remains in Fusaka, with Option A from this doc** : https://notes.ethereum.org/@ipsilon/eof_fusaka_options#A---Complete-EOF. All EIPs from `devnet-0` will be SFI'd, and those from `devnet-1` and `devnet-2` will be CFI'd. PR incoming from Danno. 
  - Most EL client teams have already shared their fork scoping preference, with EIP-7883 unanimously favored. Will CFI this too. 
  - On next ACDE, we'll finalize Fusaka scoping. The scope should reflect shipping Fusaka by EOY, and we should not add anything that could delay PeerDAS. 

3. History Expiry
  - Due to the EIP-6110 issues, we've agreed to delay dropping pre-merge history on mainnet until after Pectra. 
  - We agreed to a May 1st deadline to drop pre-merge history on Sepolia. Piper will draft an informational EIP with this info to add it to the Fusaka Meta EIP. 
  - We ran out of time to discuss the other topics on the agenda. 

4. BarnabÃ© and Ansgar announced the Protocol Reseach Call (first one next Wed 14:00 UTC): https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/protocol-research-call/23261

5. If you want to participate in post-Sepolia testnet naming discussions, you can do so here: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/testnet-name-needed-for-sepolia-replacement/23221

content: Yes, this was with some pain added to Prysm, but I believe we all had to bite that pill after Holesky, on mainnet we won't be able to quickly release and patch clients like that so at the very least we need to be able to blacklist valid blocks as invalid unfortunately

author: potuz
content: I think the broad concept we need to come to agreement eventually is how will be act, what sort of procedures will we follow, if we finalize an invalid chain. This goes beyond the social discussion that surely will happen at the time. I don't really care about even being part of those discussion, the point is that we aren't even technically prepared to roll back finality in any way. If we are going to do something like that we should at least have the options of what's technically doable, and how we will do it, how the slasher will work, and the such. I've been preparing a little document with a notion of a lazy slasher that spun up from this discussion... At the very least our slashers should be working and not be the fiasco of Holesky
